qas.question: What determined a child's social identity?
What heritage system do Southeast tribes use?
What were multiracial children with a tribal mother considered to be in tribes of the Southeast?
What race did the Omaha view a multiracial child with a white father to be?
What did not determine the social identity of the children?

plausible_answers.text: accepted as and identified as Indian

qas.question: What was the status of mixed race children in the tribes of the Northwest?
What was the child of a white woman and a Omaha man considered?
Who would not protect mixed-race children and their mothers?
Who could formally belong to the tribe if they were adopted by a woman?

context: The social identity of the children was strongly determined by <a0_0>the <b4_0>tribe's kinship system<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Among the <a1_0>matrilineal<a1_0/> tribes of the Southeast, the mixed-race children generally were <b5_0>accepted as and identified as <a2_0>Indian<b5_0/><a2_0/>, as they gained their social status from their mother's clans and tribes, and often grew up with their mothers and their male relatives. By contrast, among the patrilineal <b7_0>Omaha<b7_0/>, for example, the child of a white man and Omaha woman was considered "<a3_0><b6_0>white<b6_0/><a3_0/>"; such mixed-race children and their mothers would be protected, but the <b8_0>children<b8_0/> could formally belong to the tribe as members only if adopted by a man.
